div1.p: This report supports Ames' inclusion in the Act, approved February 28, 1929, to recognize the public service rendered and disabilities incurred as voluntary subjects for inoculation during the yellow fever investigations in Cuba.

head.hi:
Record and Supporting Evidence
In Re:- Yellow Fever Campaign in Cuba
of
Roger Post Ames

item.p: I. History of Act - sought to be amended.

The Act sought to be amended reads as follows:
“An Act to recognize the high public service rendered by Major
Walter Reed and those associated with him in the discovery of
the cause of and the means of transportation of Yellow Fever”-
Approved February 28, 1929.
1. Who Are Included in This Act.
“That in special recognition of the high public service rendered
and disabilities contracted in the interest of humanity and
science as voluntary subjects for the experimentations during
the Yellow Fever investigations in Cuba.” - twenty-three persons
wore chosen.
2. How They Were Chosen.
In a hearing before the Military Affairs Committee, the Surgeon
General, then General Ireland, assisted by Colonel J. R. Kean,
retired when asked to define and limit the classes and persons
to whom such recognition was due, arbitrarily set three classes
and named the persons.
a. The four composing the Board on the basis of their
scientific contributions, one of whom died before
the experimental work in which the others were in-
volved was begun.
b. Those who were infected voluntarily by the Yellow
Fever mosquito.
c. Those who were infected voluntarily by blood infusions.
This classification was agreed upon but not written into the Act.

list.item:
II. Roger Post Ames Should Be Included in the Act under Class a.
A. He Was Directly in Charge of the Experimental Camp.
1. “Regarding his (Dr. Ames) connection with the work of the
Yellow Fever Board, at the head of which was Major Walter
Reed, the records show that he (Dr. Ames) was on duty at
Camp Lazear, the experimental camp established by the Board
from the date of its establishment, November 20, 1900, until
February 28, 1901, on which date the camp was discontinued.”
Letter from G. H. Bridges (S) Major General, to Mrs. Roger
Post Ames, November 19, 1929.
2. “Dr. Ames was Surgeon in immediate command of Camp Jesse W.
Lazear, United States Sanitary Experimental Station near
Quemados. And he was Attending Surgeon of the United States
Army Yellow Fever Commission. A telephone connected Major
Reed's room at Columbia Barracks with Dr. Ames' tent at
Camp Lazear.” Daily Picayuno, New Orleans, July 30, 1905,
in re Yellow Fever Epidemic in that city to which Dr. Ames
had been sent by the Surgeon General to take charge of Jack-
son Barracks.
-2-
B. Command of Camp Lazear Was Not in Regular Line of Duty.
1. “This the second series of experiments began November 20, at
an experimental camp near Quemados, called Camp Lazear, and
embraced 14 cases.” Document No. 10, 59th Congress, 2nd ses-
sion, page 2.
2. “A camp was especially constructed for the experiments about
four miles from Habana, christened Camp Lazear.” Idem page 13.
3. “The necessity for an experimental camp became more imperative
as time passed. --- We immediately set about choosing a loca-
tion for our camp----on the twentieth of November we inaugurated
our camp which we called Camp Lazear in honor to the memory of
our dead colleague, consisting then of seven army tents guarded
by a military garrison.” Pages 24-25 “Inside History of a Great
Medical Discovery.” by Dr. Aristide Agramonte.
4. “Dr. Ames was Surgeon in immediate command of Camp Jesse W.
Lazear ---A telephone connected Major Reed's room at Columbia
Barracks with Dr. Ames' tent at Camp Lazear.” New Orleans
Picayune, July 30, 1905.
I have
copy the
Lazear
5. “Dr. Ames had no connection with the yellow fever Board before
the establishment of Camp Lazear; he attended the cases of
Drs. Carroll and Lazear when they came down with the fever in
the regular course of duty at Columbia Barracks.” Dr. Agramonte
to Mrs. Ames, May 27, 1930.
C. Charged With Some Responsibility In Securing Volunteers and Subjects
for the Experiment.
1. “I noticed that in Major Kean's notes recently prepared for the
Secretary to the Surgeon General, I am credited with being
offered the sum of $200 for my part in the experiments at Que-
mados. As you are the only person with whom I discussed this
matter prior to submitting to the experiments, I wish you would
kindly correct this mistake.---you told me that Major Reed was
ready to pay up to $500. You advised me to accept.---You had
made a similar offer to Mr. Parker----. Since I never discussed
the matter with Dr. Carroll and the money end was never brought
up afterwards, you are probably the only one of the entire Medi-
cal Board now living who can testify to the actual amount of-
fered me.” Letter to Dr. Ames from John J. Moran (Named in the
Act) March 14, 1907.
D. Rendered Scientific Services of Greatest Value
Roger Post Ames was a trained, scientific expert in the diag-
nosis and treatment of Yellow Fever:
1. Classed with Dr. Lazear
“The cases studied during the Quemados epidemic had been diag-
nosed by a board of physicians selected largely by reason of
their familiarity with yellow fever. This Board consisted of
Drs. Nicola Silverio, Manuel Herera, Eduardo Angles and act-
ing Assistant Surgeon Roger Post Ames and Jesse W. Lazear.”
Major Reed, U.S. Army Etiology of Yellow Fever, page 4.
2. Special Order No. 83 attached him to the Board investigating
contagious diseases in Cuba.
-3-
3. “--he was detailed---to take care of the experimental cases. He
certainly had excellent judgment and although the cases were of-
ficially confirmed by a special board, he was the first who came
in contact with them and made the earliest diagnosis.” Dr. Aristide
Agramonte to Mrs. Ames, May 27, 1930.
4. The famous case carried as XY on the records for so long was
diagnosed by Dr. Roger Post Ames upon request of Major Reed: “and
his attending physician, Dr. Roger Post Ames, U.S.A., an expert
in the diagnosis and treatment of this disease did not hesitate
to diagnose XY's attack as one of well pronounced yellow fever.
The diagnosis, therefore, not being in doubt----” Major Walter
Reed, “Etiology of Yellow Fever” page 15.
5. “His (Dr. Ames) scientific services began when a case developed;
as soon as high temperature or the least symptom appeared, the
case---was placed under Dr. Ames' charge until his final recovery.
They all recovered, a fact which we all thought was a “feather in
his cap.” Dr. Agramonte in a letter to Mrs. Ames, May 27, 1930.
6. In charge of Camp Lazear, the success of the experiment depended
upon Dr. Ames' scientific knowledge of diagnosis and treatment of
yellow fever.
“The highly dangerous character of these experiments and the
good fortune of the Board in its second and third series of
cases is shown by the fact that Dr. Guiteras, of Haban, in a
series of seven cases, innoculated in Habana, lost three bring-
ing his experiments abruptly to an end.” Senate Document #10
59th Congress, 2nd session, page 3.
"This terminated our experiments with mosquitoes which the
necessarily performed on human beings, fortunately did not
cause a single death. “Inside History of a Great Medical
Discovery” page 30. Aristide Agramonte.
See also Number 5 above.

III. Major Walter Reed Personally Depended Upon Dr. Ames' Scientific
Training.
1. “Carroll (James of the Act) has arrived and of course has given
me some of the latest news. Hanberry's chart is simply beautiful,
indeed this is an invaluable case.” Letter from Major Reed to Dr.
Ames, March 11, 1901.
2. “Now, my dear doctor, pray tell me when I may expect that map of
Quemados with your notes thereon? I am so anxious to get it, as
I need it very much in preparing a paper that I am now writing.
Please, therefore, send it right along by mail under government
stamp without waiting for Mrs. O'Reilly's case. I will appreciate
it so much if you will.” Major Walter Reed to Dr. Ames, March 11,
1901.
3. “Please accept my sincere thanks for the map of the infected Dis-
trict in Quemados together with the accompanying histories of
early and late Yellow Fever. The labor you have given to this
work is fully appreciated by me.” Major Walter Reed to Dr. Ames,
March 26, 1901.

IV. In Performing This Special Duty for the Advancement of Science, Dr.
Ames Exposed Himself to the Disease.
1. On January 26, 1901, while in line of special duty, Dr. Ames de-
veloped symptoms of Yellow Fever but he was not committed as a
patient to the hospital until January 28. He returned to duty
on February 5. Major Alec Stark attended him and signed the neces-
sary papers which are on file in the War Department.
2. “Because he was considered immune to Yellow Fever, himself claiming
to have had the disease or much contact with cases in New Orleans.
I do not know upon what basis his immunity was founded.” Dr. Agra-
monte to Mrs. Ames, May 27, 1930.
3. “I sincerely hope you have quite recovered from your recent ‘attack’
and that you are now immune to all ‘bugs’ that fly or creep.”
Major Reed to Dr. Ames, March 11, 1901.
4. In a conversation with his wife just before he was placed in charge
of Jackson Barracks in the epidemic of 1905, by the Surgeon General,
Dr. Ames spoke of his case of Fever and of his fear of death since
he had knowingly exposed himself to the disease when he took charge
of the cases in Cuba.

div1.p:
Roger Post Ames is entitled to inclusion in the above named Act:
II.
A- He was directly in charge of the Experimental Camp. Lazear.
B- This command was special and not regular duty.
C- Assisted in securing volunteers for the experimentations.
D- Rendered scientific services of great value upon the success
of which depended the success of the entire experiment.
III.
A- Major Reed depended upon Dr. Ames' scientific knowledge of
diagnosis and treatment of Yellow Fever.
IV.
A- A non-immune, Dr. Ames exposed himself and contracted the
fever in carrying out special duties in the advancement of
science.

p.hi: R E P O R T

div1.p:
The purpose of this bill is to include the name
of Roger P. Ames among those honored by the act of February 28,
1929. Although Doctor Ames's name does not appear among those
recommended by the Surgeon General of the Army to be included
in the above-mentioned act, there is no doubt that he was pres-
ent and was one of those in immediate charge of the yellow fever
experimental camp, known as Camp Lazier, near Columbia Barracks,
Cuba, the latter part of 1900 and fore part of 1901, and actually
contracted yellow fever while at the camp.

Although the report of the Adjutant General of the
Army claims that Roger P. Ames took part in or submitted him-
self in any manner to the experiments conducted by the yellow
fever board, it is plain that he was on duty at the camp, in
immediate charge, and did contract yellow fever. In view of
this fact, your committee feels that he is entitled to the honor
bestowed on others connected with these experiments.
